The idea for the backwards solos came about after a tape operator accidentally threaded a tape into the machine the wrong way. Paul McCartney— confused about what that then-unique sound was—asked if it was possible to do that for real, and so they tried. In December 2007’s Revolution in the Head: The Beatles' records and the sixties, Paul described it as “a beautiful solo” and sounding like “something you couldn’t play.”

George Harrison, wanted the backwards solo to fit the dreamlike mood of the song, so he would later spend more than five hours recording takes with producer George Martin. Harrison first wrote down the notation for the solos he wanted, reversed them, and recorded them twice; one with fuzz effects and the other without.
Please, don’t wake me, no, don’t shake me

Lennon would apparently spend his time when not on tour sleeping often under the influence of drugs, and would often have to be woken by McCartney for songwriting sessions, this line is most likely directed to McCartney who just wants to get his grind on.

When I wake up early in the morning
 Lift my head, I’m still yawning
Although this song has often been interpretated as John Lennon being in an immobilising drug euphoria however, Lennon himself claimed that he was simply talking about the joys of staying in bed.

Keeping an eye on the world going by my window
 Taking my time
Another song is explaining this same feeling one year after: Waterloo Sunset by The Kinks features a man inhabiting a paradise simply by looking the world by his window.

Please, don’t spoil my day, I’m miles away
 And after all, I’m only sleeping
This song could also act as an apology of laziness. You don’t have to wake up John for something probably useless and taking place at a long distance. Let him sleep.

Lying there and staring at the ceiling
 Waiting for a sleepy feeling
A good description of those times when you’re in bed but not at all tired. Lennon likes his bed so much that he’s just lying there waiting to become sleepy so that he can dream again.

When I’m in the middle of a dream
 Stay in bed, float up stream (Float up stream)

This is descriptive of the sensation you feel when you’re partly woken but still asleep. Lennon knows he’s in his bed but he’s so comfortable and relaxed that he feels like he’s floating up a stream. The dreamlike state is similar to floating.

Staying in bed and/or sleeping was very important to Lennon

Everybody seems to think I’m lazy
 I don’t mind, I think they’re crazy
 Running everywhere at such a speed
 Till they find there’s no need (There’s no need)

Lennon describes the song as him “dreaming his life away” with the composition and backwards guitars. The song is all about slowing down and enjoying watching the world pass you by.

Lennon was accused of being lazy, but didn’t seem to mind when he was quoted as saying:

I don’t mind writing or reading or watching or speaking, but sex is the only physical thing I can be bothered with any more."

He throws it back in their faces. John is saying he’s not the lazy one, it’s other people who are moving too fast for no reason at all.
Leave me where I am, I’m only sleeping

This line could be investigated deeper than simply discussing hit the snooze button. Sleep could be used as an expression for dreaming.

The Beatles went from lower-middle class families, and in a short time, were jettisoned to this fantastic world of wealth, adulation, fame and influence.



The experience was dream-like and perhaps they didn’t want to wake up.
